The new rules, ratified at the Football Association's Annual General Meeting on Wednesday, will apply to all the top eight tiers of English football. Players already eligible for promotion to the top division will have to receive promotion cards. They will now also be eligible for promotion at the higher levels through "legitimate clubs".

Consequently, current top-half performers will lose their automatic promotion slot for failing to gain promotions. These are expected to be players from the top two divisions, as well as those born after 1998, as well as those starting and finishing in top 20.

Top two teams will therefore gain four promotion cards and the top two clubs five, increasing a player's chance of being promoted per game per season to 15% – half what they have today.

"We've met the challenge of bringing together the science of high-tech sports such as football to deliver a more competitive environment, where top players get chances to shine and that the other teams can win and reward top talent," said FA Sport's chief executive Gary Rowett

The loan had been agreed in May 2011 by the European Union and International Monetary Fund. Since then Portugal has stuck to the strict rules required by the conditions, including imposing austerity measures and a tightened budget, according to a senior EU official. The government has been struggling to finance its enormous debt burden since the last interest payments ran out in 2016. That led to a reduction in spending and a sharp rise in unemployment, to 15 percent in April 2017.

Since the European financial crisis in 2008, Portugal and other eurozone countries have lost billions in spending and investments. In 2015 Portugal's private sector economy shrank for a third of the post-crisis period, according to the World Bank, an unprecedented decline that has left the largest state with its worst-ever economic position. With public investment in Portugal only rising at a rate of 0.5 percent between 2010 and 2015, GDP growth slowed to a third of the pre-crisis average and unemployment nearly doubled in the last 15 years.

How does a dryer air-lock work? Dryers can have electronic air-lock (EAL) technology. This can control the dryer’s operation while you sit outside. The EAL is a system used in a dryer to eliminate air from escaping to dry clothes or surfaces. It helps greatly in preserving the environment, from clean air to the heat that comes from sun to heat things indoors. Electronic locks make installing an electronic dryer system easier. The only drawback, however, is that if you lose your EAL, you have lost protection for the rest of the environment.

Stoke Field on 16 June 1487 saw the final attempt by the House of York to defend the crown after decades of war. Despite involving more troops than any other engagement of the late 16th century, the battle was inconclusive as none of the York Guards could successfully defeat Duke Robert of Wessex's military forces led by Field Marshal Stephen Leland. Both regiments withdrew from the city to finish off the army that had taken over control of England's southern frontier.

Robert had been forced to accept his throne. Although his son, Edward IV, had been elected as Prince Charles , it was still inconceivable that his brother Robert could claim the throne himself. In that sense, Lord Edward had made the right decision. By the end of the summer of 1488 the House of York would be a dynasty that would forever have the name Royal.

Former murderers, sexual offenders and other violent criminals have all been Uber drivers, allege court papers filed by district attorneys in California. They started filing charges against Uber last spring, alleging the company violated rules that drivers can legally be fired and that the ride-sharing companies deliberately underreport their number of accidents to avoid California regulations. Uber argued that underreporting is essential to complying with state rules to ensure safe ride-making . With the filings, prosecutors have provided the first glimpse at an Uber business model designed to evade California's regulations. They accuse Uber from taking illegal payment to avoid payment taxes and to avoid the penalties and risks of hiring drivers as independent contractors. The company is also accused of violating California's Race Discrimination (Anti-Harassment Law) regulations by not reporting to the state that riders may use illegal drugs or sex outside marriage.

Born on the 22nd of August, 1938, in the city of Manchester, Manchester New Hampshire , Harry Truman is a US President, US Senator and United States President Elect. He serves as the 58th President of the United States and is generally known for his energetic personality, innovative approach to business and government, and his commitment to a robust middle class. After completing higher education, he worked as a reporter for The Washington Times and served as Chief of Staff and Chief of Staff of the United States Navy for War time World War II from 1941 to 1945, with the Second Air Force, and as Under Secretary for War Personnel during the Cold War. He gained an international reputation for his dedication to his work, personal integrity, honor to his fellow Americans, and sound economic management during his 20 years of public service.

Hundreds of meteors will streak across the sky in the beautiful night show, visible around Europe's northern and northern hemispheres. The shower peaks in mid August but a rare firework streak, known as an Aurora Australis, will also dominate the sky from late August through early November.

In 2008, Aurora Australis was named for the explorer Sir William Herschel and is also known as the starburst. The name was given to the constellation of eight massive, reddish-white lights on the evening of June 30, 2012.

The show will be the longest of its kind for over 200 years with as many as 30 meteors light up per hour and can be seen with the naked eye in parts of Britain.

People in Germany and Switzerland who have taken their eyes off the skies may watch the show with some comfort.

Sir Bernard Lovell began using radio astronomy in 1945 at the opening of the fledgling Jodrell Bank Observatory. The Cheshire site would later become home to BBC3, and is now home to the European Space Agency. For two years Lovell and his students employed a system of telescopes mounted atop a hill to survey the night sky under an extraordinary starry sky, then made a fascinating discovery: Jupiter is not far behind our sun.

"Jupiter isn't just not behind the sun, it's very close to it - the sun can be right there, just behind it," explained Lovell. "And of course there is Jupiter so close to Jupiter that it's almost invisible." "It was a phenomenon, but that's all it was - a phenomenon." The bodies of 796 babies, toddlers and children were buried in unmarked graves in Tuam, County Dublin between 1925 and 1961. One of these graves was found and dug open in 1981.

This is believed to be the remains of the women and her unborn child. The baby was raised by the dead woman and raised regularly by a family of their own, usually on the nearby moorland. An investigation by Health Protection Scotland found a link to certain products produced by Highland Game. Nine people contracted the same strain of E. coli O157 after eating Highland Game products found in eight stores this summer. A total of nine stores had been found in Scotland with the same strain of bacteria. The samples tested by Health Protection Scotland matched the one sent to WHO in Atlanta, Georgia from three people with E. coli infection who tried food in the affected stores.

The contaminated beverage contained an ingredient based on the popular chocolate bar, but which contains three different additives. This suggests that the ingredient is not made using a recognised process.

The company has said it has tested all its products at home to ensure that they meet its regulations and samples have been taken from all of its premises in Scotland following the UK government's notification.

The Benin bronze, known as an "okukor", was bequeathed to Newman College in 1930 by a former British Army officer.

As the name suggests, the statue depicts a man in typical Benin garb sitting on top of a fallen angel.

The statue was purchased by the Christian church of the village of Okko in central Benin in 1930 and became the centrepiece of the local community before being sold to the British Army for $120 (£86).

It has been painted black and green, covered with mud, with a metal arm holding the statue's "angelic" body in place. Standing on top is a standing eagle.

Rocco Zito, 87, had been a member of the notorious 'Ndrangheta, or Calabrian mafia, based in Rome. He was convicted for a number of murders, among them a member of the Roman Catholic Church. He died of cancer on 27 April. He was buried in a Catholic cemetery near Rome. More details about his crime history were revealed in a BBC investigation, which aired the footage of the killings that the BBC filmed there. 'The Calabrian Mafia' was a powerful mafia from Italy's southern coast. According to its members, the Calabrian mafia was linked to Rome's medieval bloodlines, though it also had links with Italy's underworld. Most Calabrians from Calabria are members of the Calabrian Mafia . Those who escaped have fled from organized violence, mainly settling at home in Italy. The Health Survey Northern Ireland, which is published annually, also suggested the majority of people taking medicines are doing so long term. The survey of just over 4,000 people found 34 per cent of adults were taking an average of 18 pills or capsules per day. That compares with 36 per cent of the general population. In the UK the total was 51 per cent, but it was slightly higher by children (39 per cent of 15 to 19-year-olds) and those in residential care facilities (41 per cent).

Meanwhile, almost 70 per cent of medicines taken in Northern Ireland are by adults aged over 65. That is the equivalent of 14,000 pills or capsules a day, the Health Survey said.

Dr Brian Wooding, an NHS medical adviser said the survey suggested the medicines people took were "extremely concentrated."
